description: Borrowed from Latin aestimatus, past participle of aestimō, older form aestumo (“to value, rate, esteem”); from Old Latin *ais-temos (“one who cuts copper”), meaning one in the Roman Republic who mints money. See also the doublet esteem, as well as aim.

entries.meaning: A rough calculation or assessment of the value, size, or cost of something.
(construction and business) A document (or verbal notification) specifying how much a job is likely to cost.
An upper limitation on some positive quantity.

verbs.description: estimate (third-person singular simple present estimates, present participle estimating, simple past and past participle estimated)

entries.meaning: To calculate roughly, often from imperfect data.
To judge and form an opinion of the value of, from imperfect data.
